649F073351BC480AA2275AF42D97729D.description:
Model how the properties of water can change as water
moves through the water cycle.

937F8C3B0F414C029E672A6E0150A9D2.description:
Trace a path a drop of water might follow through the
water cycle.

A4107A4699A041DBA4F8510F5B6120F7.description:
Observe daily cloud patterns, types of precipitation, and
temperature, and categorize the clouds by the conditions
that form precipitation.

4CA162546E02483F9B3A672A7206A273.description:
Biogeochemical Cycles : The biogeochemical cycles in the Earth systems include the flow of
microscopic and macroscopic resources from one reservoir in the hydrosphere, geosphere,
atmosphere, or biosphere to another, are driven by Earth's internal and external sources of energy,
and are impacted by human activity.

150DEEF3E1A14C06AAFC84C40A9D9F8A.description:
Identify patterns in data collected from basic weather
instruments.

D663584C258042DFBE973CADF74A5B15.description:
Climate and Weather : Earth’s weather and climate systems are the result of complex
interactions between land, ocean, ice, and atmosphere.

661D2329EB944657B854C5B1B9ADBE58.description:
Develop a general set of rules to predict temperature
changes of Earth materials, such as water, soil, and sand,
when placed in the Sun and in the shade.

D2888A7497B348E89DE69F0A33176A4A.description: Energy in Earth Systems : Internal and external sources of energy drive Earth systems.

E004E961B4084BC894D4C9189C75A9D3.description: Categorize unknown samples as either rocks or minerals

A3439FC3C0C548BAA74181F54C67D9F6.description: Create a model to represent how soil is formed.

1B7E7EEDC0454EA7A3E2DA7873E6B3B7.description:
Properties of Earth Materials : Earth’s composition is unique, is related to the origin of our
solar system, and provides us with the raw resources needed to sustain life.

40A0C78A1A3245369087748AD381D344.description:
Use data gathered from observations of fossils to argue
whether a given fossil is terrestrial or marine in origin.

C8718C67013240DB98529C3D8D7C8A5D.description:
History of Earth : From the time that Earth formed from a nebula 4.6 billion years ago, it has
been evolving as a result of geologic, biological, physical, and chemical processes.

872C13941AA34E15889EE1D809FC97BC.description:
Analyze and evaluate evidence in the form of data tables and photographs to categorize and relate solar system
objects (e.g., planets, dwarf planets, moons, asteroids,
and comets).

AA1CF25B76B949BE9181C9A2171DD61C.description:
Generate a model with explanatory value that explains
both why objects roll down ramps as well as why the
Moon orbits Earth.

17C30215200D4FC1ADD079B4DCB958D7.description:
Identify patterns of the Moon’s appearance and make
predictions about its future appearance based
observational data.

E99B682A292F4BE884BF04F7FE019B7B.description:
Formulate a general description of the daily motion of the
Sun across the sky based on shadow observations.
Explain how shadows could be used to tell the time of
day.

F8290EC01CD7485BA81246B9C06B42D9.description:
Objects in the Universe : Our universe has been expanding and evolving for 13.7 billion years
under the influence of gravitational and nuclear forces. As gravity governs its expansion,
organizational patterns, and the movement of celestial bodies, nuclear forces within stars govern its
evolution through the processes of stellar birth and death. These same processes governed the
formation of our solar system 4.6 billion years ago.

B55F8F4E049145ECA1F02217D693C47D.description:
Earth Systems Science: All students will understand that Earth operates as a set of complex,
dynamic, and interconnected systems, and is a part of the all-encompassing system of the universe.

8E7FB32E826D4E128652DDD97C5C1010.description:
Evaluate similar populations in an ecosystem with regard
to their ability to thrive and grow.

796F1F323B4F4B3095EE84EB4EA31258.description:
Model an adaptation to a species that would increase its
chances of survival, should the environment become
wetter, dryer, warmer, or colder over time.

919F6E64C33A4C58BE23893D54C443FF.description:
Evolution and Diversity: : Sometimes, differences between organisms of the same kind
provide advantages for surviving and reproducing in different environments. These selective
differences may lead to dramatic changes in characteristics of organisms in a population over
extremely long periods of time.

624AB1CA2B164E9E9971672A42B4CB8D.description:
Compare the physical characteristics of the different
stages of the life cycle of an individual organism, and
compare the characteristics of life stages among species.

BFFFB27456B740128A22DBA9063216E3.description:
Heredity and Reproduction : Organisms reproduce, develop, and have predictable life cycles.
Organisms contain genetic information that influences their traits, and they pass this on to their
offspring during reproduction.

8C3CC9DD73ED4F569236765194ED615C.description:
Explain the consequences of rapid ecosystem change (e.g., flooding, wind storms, snowfall, volcanic eruptions),
and compare them to consequences of gradual ecosystem
change (e.g., gradual increase or decrease in daily
temperatures, change in yearly rainfall).

F26F9319ED2C45749BFCEF43AACAC9AA.description:
Predict the biotic and abiotic characteristics of an
unfamiliar organism’s habitat.

8E8269212F7A4930ACD6EFC0B82B104E.description:
Interdependence : All animals and most plants depend on both other organisms and their
environment to meet their basic needs.

74E32BC13E8F40DCBC206426EA7D9913.description:
Identify sources of energy (food) in a variety of settings
(farm, zoo, ocean, forest).

28EAFDB60DBF41EBAB3005DCA977E728.description:
Matter and Energy Transformations : Food is required for energy and building cellular
materials. Organisms in an ecosystem have different ways of obtaining food, and some organisms
obtain their food directly from other organisms.

787AB243BABC46D99F4D73976D965CC1.description:
Describe the interactions of systems involved in carrying
out everyday life activities.

F75CEE2FC2274EBB83A3D3ACA8A25028.description:
Compare and contrast structures that have similar
functions in various organisms, and explain how those
functions may be carried out by structures that have
different physical appearances.

7471A2E069D245EC909DD26C41E22F6F.description: Develop and use evidence-based criteria to determine if an unfamiliar object is living or nonliving.

4C2E527305404807AB2CEA22C07184FE.description:
Organization and Development : Living organisms are composed of cellular units (structures)
that carry out functions required for life. Cellular units are composed of molecules, which also carry
out biological functions.

08B03E4BCCED4875B8AB23C5DC8E5F67.description:
Life Science: All students will understand that life science principles are powerful conceptual
tools for making sense of the complexity, diversity, and interconnectedness of life on Earth. Order in
natural systems arises in accordance with rules that govern the physical world, and the order of
natural systems can be modeled and predicted through the use of mathematics.

B2AD3437A6CB4031914910BBDAFA82CE.description:
Investigate, construct, and generalize rules for the effect
that force of gravity has on balls of different sizes and
weights.

20EE23ECB3BB433ABE3261D0D019C21F.description:
Investigate and categorize materials based on their
interaction with magnets.

15C7E82231F04E77A684BE0C5435A78E.description: Identify the force that starts something moving or changes its speed or direction of motion.

146ADC2C190C478398421948ABA2F6F4.description:
Demonstrate through modeling that motion is a change in
position over a period of time.

266A73614101498B8A4F6D534F4042CD.description:
Forces and Motion : It takes energy to change the motion of objects. The energy change is
understood in terms of forces.

BF9B926AEC954DDCA795C79F11A6104E.description:
Repair an electric circuit by completing a closed loop that
includes wires, a battery (or batteries), and at least one
other electrical component to produce observable change.

B97B8907B9E841CEABC9A0D36A6AAEE7.description:
Energy Transfer and Conservation : The conservation of energy can be demonstrated by
keeping track of familiar forms of energy as they are transferred from one object to another.

1334D580695547C9B135736E87ABB81E.description:
Illustrate and explain what happens when light travels
from air into water.

8002DD9E895143E49A82FEF6285FDED3.description:
Draw and label diagrams showing several ways that
energy can be transferred from one place to another.

B62ED0930F14439481C494FF39348072.description:
Compare the flow of heat through metals and nonmetals
by taking and analyzing measurements.

EE9550B559ED47CA94BEA3EF17BCCAC1.description:
Compare various forms of energy as observed in everyday
life and describe their applications.

A0445194A82944EA9EBCC5374D542215.description:
Forms of Energy : Knowing the characteristics of familiar forms of energy, including potential
and kinetic energy, is useful in coming to the understanding that, for the most part, the natural
world can be explained and is predictable.

6C5B8A2CD8574AEBAABBCC2FC7956C92.description:
Predict and explain what happens when a common
substance, such as shortening or candle wax, is heated to
melting and then cooled to a solid.

C8A413A9D84E44098C33FCF3E610CBC0.description:
Changes in Matter : Substances can undergo physical or chemical changes to form new
substances. Each change involves energy.

F3C40B2A640045219ED8F7398684757B.description:
Categorize objects based on the ability to absorb or reflect
light and conduct heat or electricity.

CD6D843BD1A747D8A9A2819DFB25FB2E.description:
Determine the weight and volume of common objects
using appropriate tools.

E73157BB97BD4D5195CFA0308F2A1EBB.description:
Plan and carry out an investigation to distinguish among
solids, liquids, and gasses.

54D556CE32CD4D4898C1BAF55875F785.description:
Identify objects that are composed of a single substance
and those that are composed of more than one substance
using simple tools found in the classroom.

8ACE019D82B449E6949D8F4BC761F0D0.description:
Properties of Matter : All objects and substances in the natural world are composed of matter.
Matter has two fundamental properties: matter takes up space, and matter has inertia.

B46F9A2A9F204876BA10A8C5315ADDFE.description:
Physical Science: All students will understand that physical science principles, including
fundamental ideas about matter, energy, and motion, are powerful conceptual tools for making
sense of phenomena in physical, living, and Earth systems science.

A5331CBBAB3B4C4C85C6E2C8F5434532.description:
Handle and treat organisms humanely, responsibly, and
ethically.

AD352C6CF7B64C8B96194A27BC452344.description:
Demonstrate how to safely use tools, instruments, and
supplies.

51F399F3CB7145978465EA52552321C6.description:
Work collaboratively to pose, refine, and evaluate
questions, investigations, models, and theories.

1396920F92784AE18AE894A99D44A493.description:
Actively participate in discussions about student data,
questions, and understandings.

D28ECE89961E4CCB973C71E6B0A6A322.description:
Participate Productively in Science : The growth of scientific knowledge involves critique and
communication, which are social practices that are governed by a core set of values and norms.

27013E7D848040E28AF654DC58216CE2.description:
Present evidence to interpret and/or predict cause-andeffect
outcomes of investigations.

4FFCD52CD3614EC39F5D9919A627820B.description:
Revise predictions or explanations on the basis of learning
new information.

09E34F2B97B5484481EB5AAED8598699.description:
Monitor and reflect on one’s own knowledge regarding
how ideas change over time.

AB1983E72DE5485EAF5DC1424E78FD8E.description: Reflect on Scientific Knowledge : Scientific knowledge builds on itself over time.

FB5CCD40A4A84425B79F8C4830D17A7E.description:
Communicate and justify explanations with reasonable
and logical arguments.

F1D651E170FC4027AF03FD36AE4C94D9.description:
Measure, gather, evaluate, and share evidence using tools
and technologies.

88FDE0B790A34A7594A5826D78511CBA.description:
Design and follow simple plans using systematic
observations to explore questions and predictions.

115D3B0E801F457F8020B02AC5319F9A.description:
Generate Scientific Evidence Through Active Investigations : Students master the
conceptual, mathematical, physical, and computational tools that need to be applied when
constructing and evaluating claims.

5AAA394E73FB4E458332E9CE53DB56B1.description:
Use scientific facts, measurements, observations, and
patterns in nature to build and critique scientific
arguments.

921F0910A9804E99A0E7ED6EB31426A2.description:
Use outcomes of investigations to build and refine
questions, models, and explanations.

B6D7F74F67E0421AAD739C9CCB5A38FA.description:
Demonstrate understanding of the interrelationships
among fundamental concepts in the physical, life, and
Earth systems sciences.

A74B6C81C52E4238BA2977F76CBDADEE.description:
Understand Scientific Explanations : Students understand core concepts and principles of
science and use measurement and observation tools to assist in categorizing, representing, and
interpreting the natural and designed world.

7B4B34E9F43946AFA82F5C4D992CBC95.description:
Science Practices: All students will understand that science is both a body of knowledge and
an evidence-based, model-building enterprise that continually extends, refines, and revises
knowledge. The four Science Practices strands encompass the knowledge and reasoning skills that
students must acquire to be proficient in science.
